A Key Signature with modifications (possibly empty)

A Key Accidental is represented by a Pitch (A modification to a standard key for one pitch in the scale).
 (we're not allowed to derive instances on record types unless we use newtype)

declarations.comments:
A tuplet signature:
   put p notes into the time of q the next r notes.

declarations.comments:
A Chord Symbol definition.  Note that in ABC, this is merely a free-format string 
with recommendations in the spec of how it might be properly formatted.
We include an optional duration.  This is ignored by the parser but can 
act as a placeholder for applications such as players to calculate a duration.
declarations.title: SymbolDefinition

declarations.comments: A broken rhythm operator - one or more < or >.-}

modules.name: Data.Abc.Accidentals
modules.comments:
Accidentals are a set of mappings from a PitchClass to an Accidental
They are useful, for example, when interpreting a bar of music where
the accidental nature of a note may depend on the existence of a previous
note of the same pitch within the bar.

declarations.comments: A set of accidentals
declarations.title: Accidentals

declarations.comments: create an empty set of Key Accidentals
declarations.title: empty

declarations.comments: add an accidental to the set
declarations.title: add

declarations.comments: build Accidentals from a KeySet
declarations.title: fromKeySet

declarations.comments: lookup a pitch class and see of it exists in the Accidentals set
declarations.title: lookup

declarations.comments:
lookup a KeyAccidental (represented as a Pitch) and see if it's a member of
the Accidentals set  (i.e. the value of the Accidental matches for the supplied pitch)
declarations.title: member

declarations.comments: extract the KeyAccidental Pitch from a KeySignature
declarations.title: fromKeySig

declarations.comments:
Return an accidental if it is implicitly there in the supplied KeySet
(which is obtained from a key signature)
attached to the pitch class of the note. In ABC, notes generally inherit
their (sharp, flat or natural) accidental nature from the key signature.
declarations.title: implicitInKeySet

declarations.comments: Pretty-print a chord.

declarations.comments: Module for converting an ABC Tune parse tree to a canonical ABC string

modules.name: Data.Abc.KeySignature
modules.comments:
ABC Key Signatures and their associated scales and details of signature.
The individual (sharp or flat) keys that comprise each key signature
across all the modes in western music.

declarations.comments:
Get the key signature (if any) from the tune.
For more flexibility, you should use the _ModifiedKeySignature optic.
declarations.title: getKeySig

declarations.comments: Get the key signature properties (if any) from the tune.
declarations.title: getKeyProps

declarations.comments: The set of keys (pitches) that comprise the key signature.
declarations.title: keySet

declarations.comments: Is the pitch is in the KeySet?
declarations.title: inKeySet
modifiedKeySet

declarations.comments: Get the set of key accidentals from the (possibly modified) key (if there is one in the tune).
declarations.title: getKeySet

declarations.comments: the number of notes in a chromatic scale (12)
declarations.title: notesInChromaticScale

declarations.comments:
The set of keys (pitches) that comprise the diatonic scale governed by
the key signature.
declarations.title: diatonicScale

declarations.comments: The default key is C Major (with no accidental modifiers or other properties)
declarations.title: defaultKey

declarations.comments: Is the key signature a sharp key or else a simple C Major key?
declarations.title: isCOrSharpKey

declarations.comments: normalise a modal key signature to its equivalent major key signature
declarations.title: normaliseModalKey

declarations.comments: Transpose a key signature by a given distance.
declarations.title: transposeKeySignatureBy

declarations.comments:
a relationship between a Pitch and a note number
i.e. C is 0, C Sharp is 1 B is 11 etc.
Note that B# and B# go above the 12 notes in the scale 
because they effectively jump octave
declarations.title: pitchNumbers

declarations.comments:
the pitch number is the position of the pitch in the chromatic scale
starting at C Natural = 0 (i.e. C is 0, C Sharp is 1 B is 11 etc.)
declarations.title: pitchNumber

declarations.comments:
Get the tune Meter where present
For more flexibility, you should use the _Meter optic.
declarations.title: getMeter

declarations.comments: Get the meter defaulting to 4/4
declarations.title: getDefaultedMeter

declarations.comments: common time - 4/4
declarations.title: commonTime

declarations.comments: cut time - 2/2
declarations.title: cutTime

declarations.comments: convert the time signature to a Rational
declarations.title: toRational

declarations.comments: The pitch of a note expressed as a MIDI interval.
declarations.title: MidiPitch

declarations.comments:
Convert an ABC note pitch to a MIDI pitch.

AbcNote - the note in question
ModifiedKeySignature - the key signature (possibly modified by extra accidentals)
Accidentals - any notes in this bar which have previously been set explicitly to an accidental which are thus inherited by this note
MidiPitch - the resulting pitch of the MIDI note
declarations.title: toMidiPitch

Transform the ABC into raw MIDI but at the modified tempo

Convert an ABC note pitch to a MIDI pitch.

AbcNote - the note in question
ModifiedKeySignature - the key signature (possibly modified by extra accidentals)
Accidentals - any notes in this bar which have previously been set explicitly to an accidental which are thus inherited by this note
MidiPitch - the resulting pitch of the MIDI note

modules.name: Data.Abc.Midi.RepeatSections
modules.comments:
Handle any repeated sections when interpreting an ABC tune.
Repeats are optional and can take the form:

 -  '|: ABC :|'
 -  '|:: ABC :|'
 -  '|: ABC :: DEF :|'
 -  '|: ABC |1 de :|2 fg |'
 -  '|: ABC |1,3 def :|2,4 efg |'

the very first repeat start marker is optional and often absent

declarations.comments: initial repeats i.e. no repeats yet.  intro is not used in MIDI production
declarations.title: initialRepeatState

declarations.comments:
index a bar by identifying any repeat markings and saving the marking against 
the bar number
declarations.title: indexBar

declarations.comments: accumulate any residual current state from the final bar in the tune
declarations.title: finalBar

declarations.comments: a bar of MIDI music
declarations.title: MidiBar

declarations.comments: if true, then move the tune up an octave, else down.
declarations.title: move

declarations.comments: Move the tune up an octave.
declarations.title: up

declarations.comments: Move the tune down octave.
declarations.title: down

modules.name: Data.Abc.Optics
modules.comments:
Optics for accessing the tune headers

Remember that ABC allows for multiple headers of the same type to exist.
It's not clear how you should discriminate between them if, for example,
you want to display the main tune header on a score.  I use the convention
that the first header to be defined is the prominent one.

It's also probably not necessary that optics are needed to retrieve components of
the tune body because it's almost always necessary to process this serially.

Usage requires profunctor-optics.

To retrieve the first title:

firstOf (_headers <<< traversed <<< _Title) abcTune

To retrieve all the titles into a list:

toListOf (_headers <<< traversed <<< _Title) abcTune

Or to get the tune mode:

firstOf (_headers <<< traversed <<< _ModifiedKeySignature <<< _keySignature <<< _mode) abcTune

Or to reset the title of a tune:

set (_headers <<< traversed <<< _Title) "new title" abcTune

declarations.comments: the tune headers
declarations.title: _headers

declarations.comments: the tune body
declarations.title: _body

declarations.comments: specific headers
declarations.title: _Area

declarations.comments:

the underlying key signature
declarations.title: _keySignature

declarations.title: _keySignatureModifications

declarations.comments: the pitch class e.g. A
declarations.title: _pitchClass

declarations.comments: Tempo signature fields
declarations.title: _bpm

declarations.comments: Voice fields
declarations.title: _id

declarations.comments: key signature or voice description properties
declarations.title: _properties

Data types representing tune sections as defined by bar

simple repeats or variant repeats (voltas)

a section of the tune (possibly repeated)
with indices given by the bar number where the feature lives

modules.name: Data.Abc.Repeats.Variant
modules.comments:
Variant Repeats

support for the ABC volta construction:
   ..|1 ..... :|2 ...:|3 ....  
or ..|1,2,3.. :|4.... |    etc

declarations.comments: the active variants returned as an array of tuples (variant no - bar no)
declarations.title: activeVariants

declarations.comments: the bar number of the second variant
declarations.title: secondVariantPosition

declarations.comments: add the list of variants having this bar number position to the existing variants
declarations.title: addVariants

declarations.comments:
When supplied with:
the variant positions (map of index to BarNo)
the index of the current variant 
the BarNo of the end of the entire section
then find the BarNo of the end of the variant
(This can either be the start of the next variant or the section end)

declarations.title: normaliseVoltas

declarations.comments: the variant bar number of the specified variant number
declarations.title: variantPositionOf

declarations.comments: the maximum index we can use of the active variants
declarations.title: variantIndexMax

declarations.comments: the number of variants in the ending
declarations.title: variantCount

declarations.comments: A MIDI tick - used to give a note duration.
declarations.title: MidiTick

declarations.comments:
The tempo when the tune is being played. This is usually represented
as (for example) 1/4 = 120 - i.e. 120 querter notes per minute.
this is a consolidation of both the Tempo and the Unit Note length
which thus encapsulates everything you need to calculate the overall
tempo of the tune

tempoNoteLength - the note length of a tempo definition
bpm - the beats per minute of a tempo Definition
unitNoteLength - the length of a 'unit note' in the ABC definition
declarations.title: AbcTempo

declarations.comments: The default Tempo - 1/4=120.
declarations.title: defaultTempo

declarations.comments:
default to 1/4=120 with eighth notes as the default note length
this works out that an eighth notes last for 1/4 second
declarations.title: defaultAbcTempo

declarations.comments:
Get the raw tempo signature from the tune 
For more flexibility, you should use the _Tempo optic.
declarations.title: getTempoSig

declarations.comments:
Get the ABC tempo from the tune
This is usually more useful because it incorporates the unit note length
declarations.title: getAbcTempo

declarations.comments:
The MIDI tempo measured in microseconds per beat.
JMW!!! check
declarations.title: midiTempo

declarations.comments:
calculate the number of beats per second given by an ABC tempo
to give a simple indication of the tempo of the overall melody
note that this is independent of the unit note length
declarations.title: beatsPerSecond

declarations.comments:
Get the tempo of the tune in beats per minute from the tunes header
   (if it exists) or the default of 120 if it does not.
declarations.title: getBpm

declarations.comments:
Change the tempo of the tune by altering the beats per minute (bpm)
in the tune's tempo header (if it exists) or by altering a newly incorporated
default tempo if not.
declarations.title: setBpm

declarations.comments:
calculate the note duration when it is played (in seconds)
from an ABC note duration and tempo
declarations.title: playedNoteDuration

declarations.comments:
A standard MIDI tick - we use 1/4 note = 480 ticks.
this is known as 'ticks per quarter note' or 'parts per quarter'
in MIDI literature,  480 tends to be standard.
declarations.title: standardMidiTick

declarations.comments: Assume a standard unit note length of 1/4 and a standard number of ticks per unit (1/4) note of 480.
declarations.title: noteTicks

declarations.comments:
Find the MIDI duration of a note within a chord in standard ticks
   (1/4 note == 480 ticks)
declarations.title: chordalNoteTicks

modules.name: Data.Abc.Transposition
modules.comments: Transposition of an ABC note or tune to a new key.

declarations.comments: The default Key - C Major.
declarations.title: defaultKey

declarations.comments:
Calculate the distance between the keys (target - source) measured in semitones.
Keys must be in compatible modes.
not sure whether we need to expose this
declarations.title: keyDistance

declarations.comments: Transpose a note from its source key to its target.
declarations.title: transposeNote

declarations.comments:
transposition where the target mode is taken from the source tune's key signature
(it doesn't make any sense to transpose to a different mode)
declarations.title: transposeTo

modules.name: Data.Abc.UnitNote
modules.comments: The length of a unit note - see 3.1.7 L: - unit note length

declarations.comments:
Get the unit note length
For more flexibility, you should use the _UnitNoteLength optic.
declarations.title: getUnitNoteLength

modules.name: Data.Abc.Utils
modules.comments: A Ragbag of convenience functions, many of which get Metadata from ABC

declarations.comments:
Get the first Title (if any) from the tune.
For more flexibility, you should use the _Title optic.
declarations.title: getTitle

declarations.comments:
The amount by which you increase or decrease the duration of a (possibly multiply) dotted note.
   For example A > B increases the duration of A and proportionally reduces that of B.
   A << B decreases the duration of A and increases that of B by an even greater amount.  This function
   calculates the increase or decrease.  The new duration will be given by:

   duration * (1 +/- dotfactor i)

  i is the number of 'dot' indicators (< or >)
declarations.title: dotFactor

declarations.comments:
Normalise an ABC chord by placing the correct duration against each note
and setting the overall Chord length to Unit
declarations.title: normaliseChord

declarations.comments:
Get the duration of a chord. We consider notes in a chord to have the same 
duration (as the first such note) and must also cater for the overall chord duration.
declarations.title: chordDuration

declarations.comments: Get the overall duration of a tuplet
declarations.title: tupletDuration

declarations.comments:
check if a new stave's contents is effectively empty
(the list of bars is introduced by the Score BodyPart)
declarations.title: isEmptyStave

declarations.comments: reduce an ABC tune to a 'thumbnail' of the first two full bars
declarations.title: thumbnail

declarations.comments: remove repeat markers (used for thumbnails where we need to ignore them)
declarations.title: removeRepeatMarkers

modules.name: Data.Abc.Voice
modules.comments:
Basic support for polyphonic ABC tunes.

Where voice headers are present in the tune body, partition it
into seperate bodies, one for each voice.

In ABC, voices can be introduced like this:

V:1
abc ... 
def ...
V:2 
CDE ... 
EFG ....

or like this:

[V:1] abc ... 
[V:1] def ...
[V:2] CDE ...
[V:2] EFG

which means that we either have a self-standing voice header before each group 
of lines (which inherit this voice) or else we have an inline voice header defined 
explictly against each line.

Of course, there is nothing in the spec which prevents degenerate cases where 
both forms are present.  In this case, we'll assume inline headers take precedence

The strategy is to fold over the tune structure in the State monad.  State will be 
changed each time we come across a free-standing Voice header in the tune body.
The current voice is this unless over-ridden by an inline voice.  
The fold builds up a Map of Voices to partitioned ABC tune bodies

declarations.comments:
given a tune, find all the different voice names (labels)
no matter where they might be hiding
declarations.title: getVoiceLabels

declarations.comments:
get a map of voice name to tune (filtering the body for just that tune voice)
if there is no voice header, then the voice name is "unnamed" and attached to 
the entire tune.
If voices are found, then the title of each partitioned voice tune is set to
'Voice voice-name'
declarations.title: getVoiceMap

declarations.comments:
given a tune, partition it into multiple such tunes, one for each voice
with the title of each partitioned tune set to the voice label
where there are no voices, just return the singleton which contains
the original tune
declarations.title: partitionVoices

declarations.comments:
given a tune, partition its body into multiple such bodies 
with a separate body for each distinct voice
where there are no voices, just return the singleton which contains
the original tune body
declarations.title: partitionTuneBody
